title: Clean and Unclean Animals
shortSummary: Leviticus 11 provides detailed instructions from God to Moses and Aaron regarding which animals the Israelites may eat and which are considered unclean. This chapter establishes the dietary laws that set Israel apart as a holy nation, emphasizing obedience and holiness through distinctions between clean and unclean creatures. These laws serve to teach the people about purity and separation from defilement.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - The Wilderness Period after the Exodus

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The leader and prophet who receives God's commandments and instructs the Israelites.

keyCharacters.name: Aaron
keyCharacters.description: Moses' brother and the high priest, who assists in conveying God's laws to the people.

keyCharacters.name: Children of Israel
keyCharacters.description: The nation of Israel who are the recipients of God's dietary laws and called to holiness.

definitions.definition: Having a split or divided hoof, a key characteristic for animals considered clean to eat.
The process by which certain animals regurgitate and re-chew partially digested food, indicating they are ruminants.
Something detestable or forbidden by God, often used to describe unclean animals or practices.
A state of ritual impurity that disqualifies a person or thing from participating in holy activities until cleansed.

outline.heading: Instructions on Clean Land Animals
outline.description: God commands Moses and Aaron to instruct Israel on which land animals are clean and may be eaten, focusing on those that both chew the cud and have cloven hooves, while listing exceptions that are unclean.

outline.heading: Clean and Unclean Water Creatures
outline.description: The chapter details that only aquatic creatures with fins and scales are clean and permissible to eat, while all others in the water are declared an abomination.

outline.heading: Forbidden Birds and Flying Insects
outline.description: A list of birds considered unclean and forbidden is given, along with instructions on which flying insects may be eaten, emphasizing distinctions in God's law.

outline.heading: Laws Concerning Contact with Unclean Animals
outline.description: Regulations are provided on ritual impurity resulting from touching carcasses of unclean animals, including requirements for washing and the treatment of contaminated vessels and objects.

outline.heading: General Prohibition and Call to Holiness
outline.description: The chapter concludes by reaffirming the prohibition against eating all creeping things and calls the people to sanctify themselves and be holy, reflecting God's holiness.

application: Obey God's commands in all areas of life, including dietary instructions, as an act of holiness and devotion.
Recognize that distinctions God makes, such as between clean and unclean, teach spiritual truths about purity and separation from sin.
Maintain personal and communal holiness by avoiding what God has declared unclean, reflecting reverence for His standards.
Use God's laws as a guide to live a life set apart, trusting that His instructions are for our good and His glory.

keyVerses.text: For I am the LORD your God: ye shall therefore sanctify yourselves, and ye shall be holy; for I am holy: neither shall ye defile yourselves with any manner of creeping thing that creepeth upon the earth.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the call to holiness as the foundation for obeying God's dietary laws, reflecting His own holy nature.

keyVerses.text: Whatsoever parteth the hoof, and is clovenfooted, and cheweth the cud, among the beasts, that shall ye eat.
keyVerses.significance: This verse sets the primary criteria for clean land animals, establishing the basis for dietary distinctions.

keyVerses.text: To make a difference between the unclean and the clean, and between the beast that may be eaten and the beast that may not be eaten.
keyVerses.significance: This verse summarizes the purpose of the chapter: to distinguish clean from unclean, teaching obedience and separation.
